tossups.question: A group of signaling molecules derived from these compounds include prostaglandins, thromboxanes and leukotrienes. A deficiency of hexosaminidase a results in failure to break down gangliosides, an example of these compounds. Microdomains of these compounds found in the plasma membrane are called these compounds’ “rafts.” When attached to a (*) phosphate group, these molecules form an amphipathic class of compounds that comprise a namesake “bilayer” in the cell membrane. These macromolecules are often synthesized by the smooth endoplasmic reticulum and include triglycerides. For ten points, name this class of macromolecules that includes waxes, oils, and fats.
tossups.answer: lipids [accept lipid rafts or phospholipids; prompt on eicosanoids; prompt on fats before mention]

tossups.question: At age twelve, this leader led a movement of 60,000 young revolutionaries and informants known as the Monkey Brigade. To enforce a limit of two children per family, this leader instituted forced sterilization. The “Smiling” Buddha nuclear test was conducted under this leader, who ruled through executive decree and suspended civil liberties during a period known as the (*) “Emergency." After ordering an attack on the Golden Temple of Amritsar in Operation Blue Star, this woman was murdered by her Sikh bodyguards. For ten points, name this first and only female prime minister of India.

In a play by this author, the title character sees his own blood spell the latin phrase “Homo, fuge” on his arm. In another play by this author, a shepherd becomes the ruler of Persia after overthrowing Cosroe. The title character of a play by this author of Tamburlaine asks “Was this the face that launched a thousand ships?” after summoning (*) Helen of Troy. One of this author’s characters kills his daughter Abigail for converting to Christianity and dies after falling into a boiling cauldron. For ten points, name this English playwright who wrote of a deal with Mephistophilis in Doctor Faustus and about the villainous Barabas in The Jew of Malta.

This composer’s Requiem was adapted from the libera me movement he contributed to a prior Requiem in memoriam of another composer. In the aria “Dio di Giuda,” the title ruler of one opera by this composer promises to convert to Judaism if God prevents his daughter Fenena from being sacrificed. In that opera, the Israelites sing “Va, Pensiero,” or the (*) “Chorus of the Hebrew Slaves.” The beginning of another opera by this composer of Nabucco features a lively brindisi, or drinking song, and that opera ends with the title “fallen woman” dying in Alfredo’s arms. For ten points, name this Italian composer who depicted the tuberculosis-stricken Violetta in his opera La traviata.

Observations of these objects were used by Ole Romer to make the first quantitative measurements of the speed of light. Three of these objects experience 1:2:4 [one-to-two-to-four] Laplace resonance with one another. Cycloid-shaped ridges and valleys were observed on the water-ice surface of one of these objects. One of these objects is the most geologically active object in the (*) solar system due to tidal forces acting on it from two nearby bodies. The four largest of these objects are named for Galileo and include Io, Europa, Callisto, and Ganymede. For ten points, name these celestial bodies that orbit the largest planet in the solar system.
tossups.answer: moons of Jupiter [or equivalents; accept Galilean moons until “Galileo” is mentioned; prompt on moons or satellites]

tossups.question: This author wrote a novel in which the social climber Undine Spragg divorces and remarries Elmer Moffat. In another of this author's novels, the granddaughter of the corpulent Mrs. Manson Mingott is snubbed by high society due to her separation from a Polish noble. This author of The Custom of the Country wrote a novel in which a broken (*) pickle dish raises tensions with the main character's wife and described Newland Archer’s longing for Countess Ellen Olenska in The Age of Innocence. The title character of a novel by this author is the husband of Zeena and attempts a love suicide with Mattie. For ten points, name this author of Ethan Frome.

The Russian admiral Alexey Orlov led a failed 1770 revolt in this country. Edward Codrington was criticized by the British Admiralty for engaging an Ottoman fleet in an 1827 battle off this country’s coast. Otto I of Bavaria was the first king of this nation, whose independence was formally recognized by the London Protocol. An organization known as the (*) Filiki Eteria initiated this country’s war of independence under the leadership of Alexander Ypslantis. For ten points, name this country where, in 1832, a kingdom was established in Athens.

E.E. Evans-Pritchard studied how this phenomenon permeated the religion of the Azande people, criticizing those who believed it to be primitive. In The Golden Bough, James Frazer defined this phenomenon using a Law of Similarity and Law of Contagion. Bronislaw Malinowski described the cultivation practices used by the (*) Trobriand islanders in a work titled for Coral Gardens and this concept. The use of supernatural powers for selfish purposes by sorcerers is known as the “black” variety of this practice. Harry Houdini was a famous modern-day practitioner of this discipline. For ten points, name this practice that may be performed by witches.
tossups.answer: magic [accept Coral Gardens and their Magic]

tossups.question: A festival that honored this deity included a ceremony in which piglets were thrown into subterranean pits, in reference to the swineherd Eubouleus; that festival was the Thesmophoria. After Erisychthon cut down their sacred grove, this deity cursed him with eternal hunger. While she was disguised as an old lady, King (*) Celeus asked this deity to nurse his son Triptolemus, who later became a follower of hers. This goddess accidentally ate the shoulder of Pelops while grieving the disappearance of her daughter, who was kidnapped by Hades. For ten points, name this mother of Persephone and Greek goddess of the harvest.
tossups.answer: Demeter [accept Demeter Thesmophoros before mention, do NOT accept or prompt on Ceres]

tossups.question: The babirusa is a tusked pig species native to parts of this country. This country is roughly divided by a fauna boundary line named after Alfred Wallace. Four peninsulas make up much of the landmass of this country’s island of Sulawesi. A long-term volcanic winter may have been caused by the explosion of this country’s (*) Mount Toba 75,000 years ago. This country’s tallest point, Puncak Jaya, is found on the easternmost of its islands, New Guinea. The Strait of Malacca separates this country’s island of Sumatra from its neighbor Malaysia. For ten points, name this Southeast Asian country whose island of Java is the site of its capital of Jakarta.

A long poem titled for this place includes the sections “Bad Blood” and “The Impossible.” That poem opens by comparing the speaker’s life to “one long party where all hearts were open wide.” Locations in another poem titled for this place include the city of Dis, a frozen lake, and the Wood of Suicides. In that poem, before entering this place, the narrator encounters a (*) she-wolf, a lion, and a leopard in the woods. Arthur Rimbaud wrote a poem about “A Season in” this place, where Brutus, Cassius, and Judas are condemned to be eternally chewed For ten points, name this place where Dante sees Satan in Inferno.
tossups.answer: hell [accept l’enfer, accept Inferno before mention, accept A Season in Hell]

tossups.question: A figure in this work supposedly reached the East and the West as if he had traveled beyond the edges of his world. One episode in this work details the events surrounding the aftermath of the Battle of Badr. This text can be divided into sections known as juz so it can be read in (*) thirty days. A portion of this text condemns alcohol and gambling and is known as the “Cow”. This text can be interpreted using recited sayings known as hadiths and are chapterized into intervals known as surahs. This book was first revealed by the angel Gabriel to Muhammed. For ten points, name this holiest text of Islam.

One programmatic piece in this genre has movements titled “The Farewell,” “The Absence,” and “The Return.” That piece’s score has the word “Lebewohl” [lay-bay-vole] written over its opening three chords and is titled Les Adieux [lay-zah-DYOO]. One composer’s technically difficult twenty-ninth piece in this genre opens with fortissimo B-flat major chords and is named (*) Hammerklavier. Another piece in this genre subtitled “quasi una fantasia” opens with slow C-sharp minor triplets. That piece in this genre got its nickname because its first movement was reminiscent of the title phenomenon on Lake Lucerne. For ten points, name this genre of pieces such as Beethoven’s “Moonlight.”
tossups.answer: piano sonatas by Ludwig van Beethoven [prompt on sonatas]

tossups.question: This man and his lieutenants Crixus and Oenemaus achieved initial success due to ongoing revolts in Spain. After escaping from the school of Lentulus Batiatus, this former murmillo used grapevines to lead a group of slaves down (*) Mount Vesuvius. After Crassus defeated this man, Pompey arrived from Spain and took credit for the victory. Though this man’s body was never found, 6,000 of this man’s followers were crucified along the Appian Way after their defeat in his revolt: the Third Servile War. For ten points, name this escaped gladiator who led a revolt against Rome.

In one painting by this artist, four women on the right weep as the title figure turns away from the central action while sitting behind a statue inscribed with “DEA ROMA.” That painting by this artist depicts the death of the title Roman’s children and is titled The Lictors Bring to Brutus the Bodies of his Sons. This artist also painted a scene before a battle in which three (*) brothers salute towards three swords held by their father. The central figure in a third painting by this artist points at the sky as he prepares to drink hemlock. For 10 points, name this French neoclassical artist of The Death of Socrates.

As a teenager, Nick Kyrgios hit a between the legs winner against this player during an upset victory at the 2014 Wimbledon Championships. After winning the first two sets, this athlete was pushed to the limits in a thrilling five set win over Daniil Medvedev at the 2019 US Open Final. This man, who often uses a left-handed “lasso whip” forehand to generate spin, holds the longest single-surface win streak with (*) eighty-one wins on clay. In 2019, this player claimed his record-setting twelfth title at the French Open. For ten points, name this Spanish tennis player known as “Rafa”.

Historian Russell Kirk claimed that this party’s “most eloquent member” was Fisher Ames. A group of members of this party were accused of aiding British naval vessels as “blue-lighters” in the War of 1812 and were called the Essex Junto. Delegates from this party unsuccessfully pushed for the (*) secession of New England at the Hartford Convention. This party’s last presidential nominee was Rufus King, who was defeated by James Monroe and the Democratic-Republicans. For ten points, name this early American political party led by Alexander Hamilton and John Adams.

In one form of this technique, a thermocouple measures the temperature difference between a sample and reference pan. That form can be used to calculate the glass transition temperature and is its “differential scanning” variant. A historical version of this technique uses the latent heat of fusion of ice to calculate the change in energy of a sample. A high-pressure variant of this technique, known as the (*) “bomb” type, is used to study combustion reactions. A common version of this technique uses coffee cups, where the change in temperature of a water container is measured. For ten points, name this technique often used to find the specific heat of substances.
tossups.answer: calorimetry [accept differential scanning calorimetry or DSC or ice calorimetry or bomb calorimetry or coffee cup calorimetry]

tossups.question: One play by this playwright features a prediction that a son named Epaphus will be born after his mother is restored to human form in Egypt. Bia carries the title character of that play to the Caucasus mountains as punishment. This playwright of Prometheus Bound also wrote a play where the ghost of a slain (*) mother wakes up The Furies in order to pursue the killer, her son. A purple carpet rolled out in another play by this playwright foreshadows the death of a king in his bathtub. The title figure of a trilogy by this playwright murders Clymestra before being put on trial in Athens in The Eumenides. For ten points, name this playwright of the Oresteia.

Nanometer-scale examples of these materials that are illuminated by UV light are called quantum dots. A potential energy barrier between these materials and a metal is named for Walter Schottky. Most modern diodes contain a junction between two types of these materials. These materials are classified as (*) n-type or p-type depending on whether they have more electrons or electron holes. Impurities are added to these materials to increase their conductivity in a process known as doping. For ten points, name these devices whose electrical conductivity is in between that of an insulator and a conductor.
tossups.answer: semiconductors [accept p-type semiconductors or n-type semiconductors; anti-prompt on diode or transistor with “what materials are those made of?”]

tossups.question: A characteristic feature of these organisms called polymorphism is illustrated by gonozooids and blastostyles. They’re not plants, but these organisms utilize metagenesis whereby they alternate between asexual and sexual reproduction. These organisms employ statocysts in order to maintain balance. Organisms within this phylum use a venomous (*) nematocyst to hunt for prey. Life cycle stages for organisms in this phylum alternate between the medusa and polyp stages. The class Anthozoa is a part of this phylum, which contains coral. For ten points, name this phylum of aquatic animals that include sea anemones and jellyfish.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points, answer the following about composers who used gnomes in their music:
parts: This composer had the pianist imitate the sound of the title creatures in Dance of the Gnomes, the second of his Two Concert Études. This Hungarian composer of the Years of Pilgrimage also wrote a set of Transcendental Études.

Modest Mussorgsky, a composer from this country, included a movement called “The Gnome” in his piano suite Pictures at an Exhibition. Mussorgsky, a member of this country’s “Mighty Handful” of composers, died in this country’s city of St. Petersburg.

This Italian composer called for four timpani and a carillon in his symphonic poem La Batalla de Gnomini, or The Battle of the Gnomes. This composer also depicted the “Pines”, “Fountains”, and “Festivals” of the title city in his “Roman Trilogy”.

bonuses.leadin: Jesus performed this miracle shortly after he fed a crowd of 5,000 followers. For ten points each:
answer: Saint Peter [accept Simon or Simon Peter]
parts: Name this miracle. This miracle allowed Jesus to reach a boat and help his disciples without swimming.
Jesus walked on water in this lake in Northeastern Israel. Jesus and his apostles often traveled on this lake, and this body of water is where Jesus miraculously calmed a storm.
After this apostle sees Jesus walking on water, he asks Jesus to command him to walk on water. Jesus does so, but when this man tries to walk on water, he begins to sink.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about stress-strain curves:
parts: In the elastic region of a stress-strain curve, stress is directly proportional to strain in accordance with this law. For a spring, this law states that the force exerted by the spring is proportional to its displacement from equilibrium.
Materials often undergo this type of deformation located beyond the elastic limit of a material. Unlike elastic deformations, this type of deformation is permanent.

Materials with this property undergo plastic deformation before fracture more readily than brittle materials. This property represents a material’s ability to be stretched into a wire and is similar to malleability.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about fruits in video games:
answer: Animal Crossing: New Horizons [prompt on Animal Crossing]
parts: Donkey Kong’s hoard of these fruits are stolen by King K. Rool and his Kremlings in a 1994 platforming game. He later spends the rest of that game collecting these fruits with slippery peels.
In Celeste, Madeline employs jumps and dashes to slowly climb up a mountain where she collects these fruits, which affect the quality of the pie she bakes at the end.
In this 2020 game, the first in its series on the Nintendo Switch, the player can collect a variety of fruits, including peaches and cherries, to sell to Tom Nook for bells.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about women to whom Vice Presidents were married:
parts: This wife of the first Vice President told her husband John to “remember the ladies” while he was at the Continental Congress. This woman was also an outspoken anti-slavery advocate.

Floride Calhoun, the wife of John C. Calhoun, led wives of cabinet members in ostracizing Peggy Eaton during this event. This event likely contributed to the rift between Andrew Jackson and John C. Calhoun.

Though she died before he became Vice President, Sarah Tappen was married to George Clinton, who also served as the first governor of this state. George’s nephew DeWitt built a construction derisively nicknamed his “folly” while governing this state.

bonuses.leadin: This process is described by Fick’s law, which states that the flux of this process is proportional to the gradient of concentration. For ten points each:
parts: Name this process in which particles travel from regions of high concentration to regions of low concentration. When this process occurs with water, it is called osmosis.
Along with Marian Smoluchowski, this scientist names an equation that relates the diffusion coefficient of a system to the mean speed and mean free path of the particles.

Einstein theorized that the diffusion coefficient was related to this process, the random motion of particles suspended in a fluid. This process was first observed with pollen grains in water by its namesake Scottish botanist.

bonuses.leadin: This novel begins with the line “Ours is essentially a tragic age, so we refuse to take it tragically.” For ten points each:
answer: David Herbert Lawrence [or D. H. Lawrence]
parts: Name this novel whose publication led to obscenity charges against Penguin Books. This novel’s title character, Constance, has an affair with the gatekeeper Oliver Mellors.
Lady Chatterley’s Lover was written by this British author, who also wrote about Ursula and Gudrun Brangwen in his novel Women in Love.
Lawrence also wrote this novel, in which the artist Paul Morel refuses to commit to relationships with Clare and Miriam Dawes because of his passionate love for his mother Gertrude.

bonuses.leadin: Howard Zinn wrote a “people’s history” of this country. For ten points each:
answer: United States of America [or United States]
parts: Name this country, the subject of Frederick Jackson Turner’s “Frontier Thesis.” The historian Eric Foner wrote much about a period succeeding this country’s civil war.

Foner also wrote a non-fiction work on this leader who led an 1831 slave rebellion in Southampton County, Virginia. Thomas Ruffins Gray published an account titled for the “Confessions” of this preacher.

Hiram Chittenden, another American historian, wrote a biography of Joseph La Barge, a steamboat captain employed by a company in this industry. Jim Bridger and Jedediah Smith were among “mountain men” who used trappers to obtain this good, which made John Jacob Astor the richest man in America.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about gold in literature:
answer: Water Margin [accept Outlaws of the Marsh, Tale of the Marshes, All Men are Brothers, Shui Hu Zhuan]
parts: This American author wrote about Bruce Gold, who becomes the first Jewish Secretary of State, in the novel Good as Gold. Milo Minderbinder and Colonel Cathcart feature in this man’s most famous novel.
A Vikram Seth novel that follows John Brown and his fellow yuppies is set in this California city, where the title Golden Gate Bridge is located.

This work inspired the later Chinese novel The Plum in the Golden Vase, also known as The Golden Lotus. At the beginning of this work, which is attributed to Shi Na’ian, Marshal Hong frees the 108 Spirits from their imprisonment.

bonuses.leadin: This artist made two paintings titled Europe after the Rain. For ten points each:
parts: Name this German artist who pioneered the frottage style of rubbing two surfaces to produce paintings. This artist also painted Two Children are Threatened by a Nightingale.

Max Ernst was a member of this artistic movement, whose manifesto was written by Andre Breton. Members of this post World War I movement were influenced by Dadaism and often depicted dreamlike imagery.

This Spanish surrealist used his wife as a model for many of his works, such as when he broke up her face into a series of spheres in Galatea of the Spheres. He also depicted his wife’s dislike for bullfighting in his The Hallucinogenic Toreador.

bonuses.leadin: This country had a colony at Tianjin in China. For ten points each:
answer: Kingdom of Belgium [accept Koninkrijk België, accept Royaume de Belgique, accept Königreich Belgien]
Italy [or Italian Republic, Repubblica Italiana, Italia, Kingdom of Italy, Regno d’Italia]
parts: Name this country whose capital is Brussels. This country’s other colonial ventures included a stint in Guatemala and as co-ruler of the Moroccan Tangier International Zone.
Belgium also had a colonial presence in this country where Romeo Dallaire was sent to lead a peacekeeping force. Dallaire later documented atrocities here in his book Shake Hands with the Devil.

After World War I, Albert I of Belgium was briefly granted an island in this country’s Lake Como. This country’s region of Lombardy was annexed from Austria after Count Cavour orchestrated a victory in the Franco-Austrian War.

bonuses.leadin: These organisms are represented by the y parameter in the Lotka-Volterra equations. For ten points each:
answer: Isle Royale [accept Isle Royale National Park]
parts: Name these organisms that kill and consume prey. Examples of these organisms that are the top of the food chain are called their “apex” variety.
The Lotka-Volterra equations have been used to model the populations of wolves and moose on this island located in the northern region of Lake Superior.
The accuracy of the Lotka-Volterra equations is reduced when the prey undergoes adaptations, such as the “Batesian” form of this phenomenon in which a harmless species poses as a harmful species.

bonuses.leadin: This modern-day country was home to a sultanate nicknamed the “porch of Mecca.” For ten points each:
parts: Identify this country, whose westernmost province, Aceh, sought independence during a nearly 30 year-long insurgency. During that conflict, which began in 1976, the GAM movement fought soldiers from this country.
The insurgency ended shortly after this kind of event in 2004. That one of these events registered a 9.3 on the Richter scale, and caused a subsequent tsunami.

The insurgency in Aceh broke out under this Indonesian dictator, though he resigned in 1998 before the insurgency ended. This man, who implemented the New Order policy, succeeded Sukarno after putting down the 30 September Movement.

bonuses.leadin: In September 2020, a warlord based in this country who holds United States citizenship was sued by relatives of his alleged victims who live in Virginia. For ten points each:
answer: Islamic State [or IS or Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant or ISIL or Islamic State of Iraq and Syria or ISIS or the Islamic State of Iraq and ash-Sham or Da’esh or Da’ish]
parts: Name this country where General Khalifa Haltar oversees a Tobruk-based component of its national army. This country’s city of Benghazi has been the subject of heavy fighting during an ongoing civil war.

One of the main belligerents in the Libyan Civil War is a faction of this terrorist organization, who declared its caliphate at Mosul in 2014. It gained prominence for its beheadings of Westerners under the leadership of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

Among the countries supporting Libya’s eastern forces in the civil war includes this country who is ruled by the House of Al Thani. Under its current leader Sheikh Tamin, this country has supported the Syrian rebel group Al-Rahman Legion.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about projective geometries:
parts: Projective geometries are represented by this type of geometry plus additional “points at infinity.” The namesake of this type of geometry published a set of five axioms for this type of geometry in the Elements.

Unlike Euclidean geometry, lines with this relationship can intersect at a point at infinity in projective geometry. Lines with this relationship in Euclidean geometry do not intersect with one another and are the subject of Euclid’s fifth postulate.

A common projective geometry involves projecting one of these objects onto a plane, with the north pole being the point at infinity. Coordinates named for these three-dimensional objects include a radius term and two angle terms.

bonuses.leadin: This architect became known as the “Queen of the Curve” due to the flowing appearance of many of her buildings. For ten points each:
answer: Summer Olympic Games [or Summer Paralympic Games]
parts: Name this Iraqi-British architect. Her “double pebble” design for the Guangzhou Opera House was meant to depict two rocks washed away by the Pearl River.

Hadid also designed the London Aquatic Centre for one of these events in 2012. Ai Weiwei helped design the “Bird’s Nest” Stadium to be used in one of these international sporting events in Beijing in 2008.

In 2006, Hadid received an honorary doctorate from this university at which she had once been a visiting professor. Eero Saarinen designed this Ivy League university’s Ingalls Ice Rink, which is commonly referred to as “the Whale.”

bonuses.leadin: A poem describing the beginning of this conflict ends with the speaker declaring that despite being “beleaguered by negation and despair” he will “show an affirming flame." For 10 points each,
parts: Name this conflict whose beginning is described in a poem set in “one of the dives on Fifty-second street."
This Anglo-American poet wrote “September 1, 1939” to describe the beginning of WWII. He also wrote a poem beginning “Stop all the clocks” about the death of his lover, that poem is Funeral Blues.

Auden began many of the stanzas of a poem he later disavowed named for this country with the word “yesterday." Robert Jordan fights the forces of Francisco Franco during this country’s civil war in Ernest Hemingway’s For Whom The Bell Tolls.

bonuses.leadin: In The Life You Can Save, this man outlined a scale for how much people should give to the poor based on income. For ten points each:
parts: Name this Australian philosopher. This man discusses applied ethics in his book Practical Ethics.

Peter Singer is a proponent of the “effective” variety of this philosophical position developed by thinkers like John Stuart Mill. This view holds that we should work to achieve the greatest good for the greatest number of people.

Singer popularized the term “speciesism” in a 1975 work supporting this cause. A group of philosophy students known as the “Oxford Vegetarians” are widely viewed as the modern founders of this movement, which is supported by groups like PETA.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer some questions about the goddess Sedna, who drowns when she is thrown out of a boat by her father, Anguta:
answer: [10] Sedna is a goddess of this place. In some myths, she grows a fishtail while living here.  ANSWER: the ocean [accept sea or other equivalents]
Inuit [accept Inuk, do not accept or prompt on “Eskimo”]
parts: Sedna is a goddess of this place. In some myths, she grows a fishtail while living here.
While some cultures consider Anguta a creator god, he is also depicted as one of these spirits who escort the dead to the afterlife. The Greek god Hermes was often referred to with this epithet.
Sedna and Anguta are gods of these people, whose other deities include the polar bear god Nanook and the Caribou Master.

bonuses.leadin: In this short story, the main character’s husband has a fond liking of beef stew. For ten points each:
parts: Name this short story by Guy de Maupassant [GHEE du moh-pa-SAW] in which Mathilde Loisel [mah-TEELD lwah-ZELL] loses the title piece of jewelry from Madame Forestier, [faw-rest-YAY] and works for ten years to pay it back only to find out that it was fake.

In Maupassant’s story “Ball of Fat," the sound of this song “in the popular air evidently did not find favor” with the crowd. Cornudet annoys passengers on a carriage by whistling this French national anthem.

In Maupassant’s short story “Le Horla," the narrator is terrorized by this kind of creature. The narrator first sees this type of creature after waving to a Brazilian boat on the Seine, and its presence eventually leads him to burn down his own house.
